Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Prompting Effective Active Learning through Implementing Self-Regulated Learning Assessment in Diverse STEM Learning Settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Jackson State University seeks to improve African American students' academic performance and retention in STEM fields through enhancing their awareness of their own abilities to learn complex STEM subjects, improving their ability for selecting and using cognitive and metacognitive strategies, monitoring their learning process and making necessary adjustment in their learning efforts. The findings from the project can be used to inform future practice in and research on developing expertise of STEM faculty and assisting students to acquire self-regulated learning skills.

The project has the following three objectives: 1) To provide STEM faculty members with professional development opportunities for obtaining skills and knowledge in educational theories through implementing the self-regulated learning assessment and by participating in a teaching community with learning scientists; 2) To provide African American students with deliberate training opportunities in multiple STEM courses for improving their skills for effectively managing their STEM learning efforts and obtaining a deeper understanding of the subject through implementing the self-regulated learning assessment in their STEM courses; and 3) To provide evidence-based data to confirm the effectiveness of proposed faculty professional development model and student skill training model and to identify factors that can facilitate obtaining desirable outcomes from the two models. The proposed activities and strategies are evidence-based and the implementation is guided by an evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to (1) implement the Self-Regulated Learning (SRL) assessment in the multiple STEM courses and examine its impacts on students’ learning performance and behaviors, and (2) establish the teaching community of STEM faculty members and learning scientists and maintain its activities for sharing knowledge in educational theories and their experience in teaching and implementing the SRL assessment.


When the SRL assessment was implemented in specific courses, the instructors assigned three classroom quizzes related to course subjects and integrated these quizzes with the SRL assessment questionnaires. At the beginning of the courses, students were given pre-tests, including the self-report questionnaires of Knowledge of Learning Strategies Survey about cognitive and metacognitive learning strategies. Besides, open-ended questionnaires of Cognitive and Meta-Cognitive Strategy Applications were adopted to solicit students’ own descriptions on their application of learning strategies. These questionnaires may prompt students to think about their learning and application of learning strategies related to SRL. When taking quizzes, students were asked to make a self-efficacy assessment on how confident they were in correctly doing the quizzes and also prompted to think of their learning processes and strategies they used for preparing the quizzes before they started working on quizzes. After finishing quizzes, students were then asked to assess their confidence in correctly doing the quizzes again. When the corrected quizzes were returned to students, they were provided the opportunity to evaluate whether learning strategies they used were effective or not and given a chance to correct their errors and learn from their mistakes by completing the self-reflection forms. 


Implementation of the project provides training opportunities for about African American students each year in multiple STEM courses on how to effectively learning through promoting them to think of their learning and application of learning strategies. The teaching community established through the project provides professional development opportunities for STEM instructors to learn educational theories and share their teaching experience by interacting with learning scientists and their peers.


Results from analyzing the collected data may reveal the following findings.

 

The SRL assessment intervention may benefit students’ learning in terms of their subject knowledge improvement in the specific courses. This benefit may mainly be attributed to the step-by-step intervention procedures that promote students to think of their mistakes and offer them a chance to correct their errors in their learning of the specific course subjects. However, the intervention may have a significant negative impact on students’ overall learning performance in other courses. These negative impacts may be because the intervention attracts students’ efforts from the other courses that did not implement the SRL assessment intervention to the specific course and make students have less time for learning subject knowledge in the other courses.

 

The SRL assessment intervention may not produce significant positive impacts on students’ learning behaviors. This may be due to that students’ learning behaviors students were not measured objectively. Or, this may be because students had to make more efforts to follow the steps specified by the intervention in the specific course and had less time to manage their learning behaviors in other courses. Besides, students may not be able to internalize and generalize the learning strategies conveyed by the intervention in their general learning well.

 

The students’ pre-semester GPAs may be a good predictor of their post-semester GPAs and their learning behaviors, while students’ pre-test CI scores may only be a good indicator of students’ post-test CI scores.

 

Based on these findings, it may be speculated that an effective way of improving students’ learning behaviors and their overall learning performance may be achieved through implementing the procedures of the intervention in all courses that students take. This may eliminate the causes for the negative impact of the intervention through helping students in internalizing and generalizing learning strategies and avoiding unbalanced distributions of their learning efforts among all courses.

 

It should also note the limitation of the reported project findings. First, the data used in the analysis were collected from an HBCU, where more than 80% of students are African American students.  Its findings may not be applied to other students’ population. Secondly, while the data analysis only assumes that the preconditions in terms of pre-test CI scores or pre-semester GPAs may have joint impacts along with the intervention on the measured outcomes, and may not consider other impacting factors. Thirdly, the students’ learning behaviors were measured through self-report questionnaires that may not accurately reflect their real learning behaviors. More accurate measures of students’ learning behaviors should be considered, including students’ learning traces and processes captured by the computerized learning system, such as an artificial intelligent tutoring system. The aforementioned speculation and approaches to overcoming the limitations associated with the current research may form the future direction in this line of research.
